doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/MS/Saudi Telecom Company SJSC STC Data centers a big growth opportunity but valuation remains unconvincingSaudi Telecom Com_2025-08-29

passages.text: August 29, 2025 03:40 PM GMT

We update forecasts to reflect Q2 results. The efficiency program should continue to back up solid EBITDA growth, while we see the data center market as a lucrative opportunity in KSA (Center3 recently raised their capacity goal by \(+250MW\) to 1GW). Valuation remains uncompelling however. Equal-weight.

STC's domestic top line saw a slowdown in Q2 after stronger Q1 gth (Q1: \(+2.6\%\) Q2: \(+1.7\%\) ). However, Group revenue and EBITDA growth picked up vs the first Qtr; Despite good momentum in the Commercial Unit (Q1: \(+1.7\%\) , Q2: \(+3.9\%\) ), the Business Unit weakened (Q1: \(+9.7\%\) , Q2: \(- 3.9\%\) ) driven by the Public segment; Q2 call focused on subsidiary performance, the efficiency program, data centers (expect increased capex led by DCs), and M&A (lots of early stage discussions); Data centres remain a key focus. We see the KSA market growing 7x by the end of the decade, with STC well poised to capture part of this growth; Our Price Target remains SAR 45/sh. FCF valuation is uncompelling (2026e ECF yield of \(5.5\%\) ), leaving us Equal- weight.

Background. i. STC shares have returned \(+14\%\) YTD (incl DPS). This represents outperformance of \(+22\) ppts vs the local Saudi stock market index, but an underperformance of - 1ppt compared to Mobily (Exhibit 1). ii. Q2 results slightly missed consensus expectations, on both the top- line and EBITDA, even if EBITDA growth did accelerate (+2.5%, Q2: \(+7\%\) , YoY); iii. The operational efficiency program continues to progress (3 year program, began in 2024), with the company expecting additional transformative initiatives to take place in the remainder of 2025 and into 2026. We introduced our Global data center model earlier this summer, projecting capacity in the KSA to reach \(>4\) GW by 2035e (from 300MW in 2024a). Indeed, on the Q2 call, STC noted that they expect an increase in capital intensity over the next 2- 3 years due to the demand they are seeing in the DC market.

Efficiency program should continue to help EBITDA. We forecast a \(+5\%\) annual EBITDA growth (2025- 28e, avg) as the efficiency program continues to progress. Following two quarters of solid EBITDA growth this year (Q1: \(+5.3\%\) , Q2: \(+7.0\%\) ), we expect a slight dip into negative growth for Q3 (- 1.3%) mainly due to a reversal that occurred in the previous year that the company will not benefit from again this year. However, we expect growth to rebound in Q4. As some of the newer subsidiaries
MORGAN STANLEY & CO. INTERNATIONAL PLC+
Saudi Telecom Company SJSC (STC) (7010.SE, STC AB)

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.
continue to grow and eventually break even (STC Bank, IoT, Specialized, SCCC etc), we believe this could be a further boost to EBITDA.

KSA data center market to grow 7x by 2030e. i. The Saudi DC market remains relatively small, with c 300MW of current installed capacity (compared to c 1.3GW in London and c 1.1GW in Dublin); ii. We see a number of reasons for very strong projected DC growth in the KSA including the Kingdom's Vision 2030 plan including a \(\) 100bn\(investment in AI and DCs and US President Trump's visit which saw a number of landmark DC and AI announcements (eg creation of PIF - backed HUMAIN); iii. Ambitious expansion projects from AWS, Khazna (aiming for 25% market share in Saudi Arabia) and Center3 (capacity could reach 1GW) will be key contributors in the growing market; iv. On STC's Q2 call management noted that they have major plans for DC expansion and that they expect an increase in capital intensity (of c 1.0- 1.5ppt) for the next 2- 3 years (more back- end loaded), due to DC build; v. STC's data center subsidiary, Center3, subsequently expanded their capacity target to 1GW by 2030 (previously 750MW), with an addt' \(\) 10b\(investment plan.

Share price remains at SAR 45/sh, valuation not compelling (MS opinion). i. We update our model to include Q2 results. Our revenue forecasts stay largely unchanged, while EFFC increases \(c + 2.5\%\) (lower capex than expected in H1, slightly higher EBITDA next year from efficiency program). Our target price remains at SAR 45/sh. ii. Our updated estimates suggest that STC offers a 2026e EFFC yield of 5.5%. Over the LTM, STC has been trading below Middle Eastern peers Mobily and e& on a NTM FCFE yield basis (Exhibit 6); iii. STC's dividend yield of \(c 5\%\) (MSe) is attractive, but largely in- line with the Saudi 10- yr sovereign.
STC has seen solid share price performance YTD, returning \(+14.3\%\) (including dividends).

- While the stock has outperformed the local TASI index by \(+22\) ppts, it has lagged behind local Saudi Telco peer Mobily by -1ppts;- Furthermore, STC's performance has lagged Middle Eastern peer e&, as well as European Telco peers Orange and Telefonica (although STC has less exposure to M&A - a key theme in European telecoms).
Exhibit 1: STC has outperformed European and Saudi indices YTD, but lags global and ME Telco peers
Exhibit 2: LTM total returns for STC have been slightly more lacklustre
The Saudi data center market remains relatively small, with ca 300MW of current installed capacity. The capital city of Riyadh has emerged as the primary Saudi DC hub -
while secondary DC markets comprise Jeddah and Dammam.
We forecast explosive growth in KSA DC capacity - from 300MW (2024a) to \(>4GW\) (2035e). This 13x increase is perhaps not surprising, given:

- AI/DC announcements made upon US President Trump's recent visit to the Kingdom - eg the formation of HUMAIN;- Kingdom investment projects including The Line (Neom);- Ambitious expansion plans disclosed by Khazna, STC, AWS etc;- The availability of investment capital; and- Abundant supply of cheap energy etc.
Exhibit 3: We forecast a 13x rise in DC capacity (across the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia) over the coming decade
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates
We have seen a number of recent AI/data center announcements, notably during the recent May 2025 visit of President Trump to the Kingdom. These include:

- A JV between AWS and PIF-backed HUMAIN, which will oversee the roll-out of up to 500MW of DC capacity via \(5bn of AI investments (incremental, beyond the\) 5bn AWS had previously committed to invest, in 2024);- Nvidia has announced it will sell 'several hundred thousand' chips to HUMAIN starting with a first tranche of 18,000 Blackwell chips;- Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) signed a \(10bn collaboration with HUMAIN to build 500 MW of AI hardware;- Qualcomm has signed an MOU to build a data center central processor;- The Saudi firm Datavolt will invest\) 20bn in US infrastructure (DCs and energy).

Interestingly, the UAE data center developer Khazna disclosed in an April 2025 interview that they are "hoping to get at least 25% market share" in Saudi Arabia. Despite many start- up developers in the market, CEO Alnaqbi has noted "None of them have the experience to handle the hyperscalers, in terms of design, delivery and operation".

Recent regulation that personal and financial data must be stored in local data centers will create further demand by global companies to have facilities within Saudi Arabia to avoid losing any contracts. As previously stated, during a guest lecture at Standford University, Abdullah Alshawha (Saudi Minister of Communications and IT) stated the country is currently building close to 2GW in computing capacity. Based on this assumption, Khazna could be looking to build c. 500MW of capacity in the coming years (MSe). Khazna has identified two (yet unnamed) locations for these DC facilities in the Kingdom.

Consistent with KSA's 2030 vision, STC is aiming to build a digital and DC hub (across Saudi, but also the broader Middle East). Driven by this strategy, in October 2022, STC launched Center3 (previously called MENAHub). This is an integrated DC platform that will provide Hyperscalers, gaming and content providers, cloud providers and global international carriers with flexibility and speed to serve regional customers. Partners and clients include five Hyperscalers and \(>20\) content providers.

In early 2025, STC announced it would partner with AWS, to launch Cloud / Al services for multiple sectors, including government, education, healthcare, finance, energy, sports, industrial etc. STC has been designated as a System Integrator Premier partner for AWS (Amazon's highest tier partner). According to Riyadh Muawad, Chief Business Officer at STC: "AWS shares our vision of advancing the Kingdom's digital transformation. Through this strategic collaboration, the Group strategy and its subsidiaries to target critical sectors in the Kingdom, we will create cutting- edge solutions, develop local talent, and pave the way for a digitally advanced future in Saudi Arabia."
STC currently has ca 350MW of data center capacity - either in operation or under construction (we believe the latter is the far greater component). In terms of the existing DC portfolio:

- STC owns 25 DCs across Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait;- DCs situated across the Kingdom include Riyadh (capacity recently increased by ca +10MW), Dammam (20MW), AlKhohar (25MW), Khurais Riyadh etc.

STC is working to expand its portfolio to reach 1GW by 2030 (increased in August 2025 from the previous 750MW target). The target was increased due to "surging regional demand for Al, cloud, and hyperscaler services" the company noted in their press release. The data center expansion will cover not only KSA, but also the broader MENA region.

The 1GW target would equate to roughly the current scale of the London data center market in Europe (one of the core Big Five European FLAPD territories). We have discussed the potential valuation of STC's data center portfolio in previous notes (Data center portfolio: Strong growth, significant valuation potential (27 Sep 2024)).
We update our model following the recently published Q2 2025 results. In terms of key changes:
- Our domestic/KSA and Group revenue forecasts (2025-28e) stay largely

unchanged (ca -40bps lower, on average);- The Group EBITDA outlook also remains largely as before, although we slightly increase 2026e estimates (by ca +1.5%) in light of the continued cost optimization program;- Our ECFC estimates rise c +2.5%, mainly due to slightly lower capex this year.
Exhibit 4: STC: Estimate changes, post slightly disappointing Q2 2025 results
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates
Our Price Target remains SAR 45/share. We believe there is limited visibility on some of the firm's subsidiaries, thus we keep our estimates largely unchanged.
Our updated forecasts suggest that STC offers a 2026e ECFYield of \(5.5\%\) (based on ECF of SAR 11.3bn in FY 2026e).
This compares with ca \(7\%\) for DT and ca \(9\%\) for Orange, in Europe; Meanwhile, STC continues to trade at a discount relative to Middle East peers Mobility and e& (Exhibit 6).
The dividend yield of \(c5\%\) (MSe), while attractive, is largely in- line with the Saudi 10- year sovereign yield.
Exhibit 5: ECFC waterfall - drivers of our 2026e ECFYield of ca \(5.5\%\)
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates
Exhibit 6: Over the last 12 months, STC has traded at a discount to ME peers Mobility and e&
Source: Workspace, Morgan Stanley Research

We base our price target on a DCF, applying a \(4.0\%\) risk- free rate (below the current SAIBOR rate, but more reflective of the longer- term average), \(6.25\%\) equity risk premium and \(3.5\%\) cost of debt (current implied level). We assume a \(+2.0\%\) terminal growth rate.
- Stronger market growth, KSA Telco industry price rises- Further special dividends- Valuation of Tech start-ups & data centre portfolio
- Net cash used for dilutive acquisitions / M&A- Sustained weakness in the KSA Telco B2B market- More hawkish regulation

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
